Award.AwardTitle: Big Ten Academic Alliance Summit on Advancing Undergraduate Women in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by promoting strategies and opportunities to improve the representation and success of women of color in STEM. Equal access to scientific inquiry and STEM careers is an important goal for the National Science Foundation and for the nation as a whole, yet minority students, particularly women of color, are not participating in the scientific enterprise in numbers representative of the general population. This workshop proposes to identify challenges and strategies to address this inequity within the context of the institutions of the Big Ten Academic Alliance. Faculty and administrators from the Big Ten campuses will gather at Rutgers University on June 5-8, 2019 to engage in discussions with campus leaders and campus climate experts to identify challenges and develop strategies to promote achievement and advancement of undergraduate women of color in STEM.

Participants will examine survey data collected from Big Ten campuses to identify effective strategies and practices in use on individual campuses. Inter-university working groups will then develop plans for implementing these strategies across campuses. Working groups will establish program goals and develop plans for effective evaluation. Workshop results will be collected in a written report circulated to Big Ten provosts and distributed to national outlets. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the Big Ten Summit Series on Advancing Women in STEM is to discern institutional strengths and challenges, collaborate on scalable and transferrable practices, and establish sustainable partnerships across the Big Ten Universities for continued innovation and collaboration. The first Summit, held in June 2019, centered on undergraduate women in STEM: this Summit supported existing efforts at participating universities while spearheading new ones through a fresh application of national best practices and new cross-institutional synergies across the Big Ten Academic Alliance. During the first Summit, Rutgers hosted renown keynote speakers; coordinated inter-institutional working groups centered on three areas of practice: overall best practices for recruitment and retention of undergraduate women in STEM, best practices for recruitment and retention for undergraduate women of color in STEM, and best practices for assessment and evaluation; and outlined steps for continued collaborations. The ultimate goal has been to establish the framework and begin work to build a community of practice for expanding the STEM pathway and to chart channels for new collaborations within Universities and across Big Ten Academic Alliance partners. Specific outcomes include a collection of best practices from inter-institutional working groups, the establishment of University teams to further those best practices at participating institutions, and new collaborations across institutions.

Since the 2019 Summit, Rutgers has hosted monthly virtual meetings and two follow-up conferences to further the Summit?s working group recommendations and to define goals and best practices for participating institutions to overcome barriers and to create best practice opportunities to increase representation of women of color in STEM across our campuses.

Continued activities will focus on two strategic goals to move the initiative forward:

  • Research and implement best practices designed to increase the percentage and improve the experience of women of color (WOC) in STEM (recruitment, retention, graduation, post-graduation).
  • Increase collaboration among the Big Ten Academic Alliance Group. This goal helps establish the needed infrastructure to sustain the group. We have continued to hold meetings since the 2019 Summit in order to carry out this goal. Additionally, we received an invitation from Cognizant U.S. Foundation to submit a proposal for a sponsored common pilot project, to be determined, and this will constitute a third track populated by the pilot schools, with a feedback loop to the whole.

In sum, over the life of this award, significant progress has been made toward fulfilling the project goals. The work continues at three levels: the University level, the institutional level, and as a Big Ten Academic Alliance working group team. The Big Ten Academic Alliance working group team has become a clearing house for critical information and data sharing related to women in STEM and for creating opportunities for a common project, such as a student conference, college grant proposals across participating institutions.
